Situation1: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I stared at my phone, the court summons glowing on the screen. As a police officer, I knew my duty was clear: I had to testify, to uphold the law with integrity and fairness. The case was important, and my testimony could make a real difference. But then I glanced at my watch—my volunteer shift started in less than an hour. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center this morning, and I could already picture the line of people waiting outside, relying on me to open the doors and start the day’s service. They counted on me to be there, on time, every time. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides. If I missed court, I’d be failing my duty as an officer. If I missed my shift, I’d be letting down the people who needed help the most. The clock ticked on, and I felt the pressure mounting, torn between two promises I’d made.
